title: Super blowout prolongs government's wait to spend Future Fund returns
text:
"It will take longer to match the superannuation liabilities and therefore the government won't really be able to draw on the Future Fund for other things."

He said that it would ultimately depend on how long interest rates remained low and also on the rate of retirement by public servants eligible for the very generous defined-benefit super schemes.

Finance Minister Mathias Cormann said the provision for the unfunded super liability was affected by budget accounting rules and the assumed discount rate would continue to "move around" over the coming years.

The Future Fund would help "bridge the gap", he said.

Phased approach

"It's not something the government will have to pay today, it is something that will continue to be dealt with in a phased approach," he told a Senate hearing on Tuesday.

Senator Cormann reaffirmed that the Morrison government would not dip into the Future Fund to pay for other government spending, as it would be entitled to do from July 2020 under the legislation.

"Because of the adjustment in discount rates, in our view it reinforces the decision we've made to let the Future Fund to continue to invest and achieve very high returns against the very low interest rates that are paid on public debt interest."

Advertisement

The Future Fund, however, will prop up federal budget surpluses by $17 billion in expected investment earnings from 2020-21 onwards for the first time, under a delayed accounting change made in 2012 by Labor's then finance minister Penny Wong

Almost 40 per cent of the government's $45 billion of projected surpluses over the next four years were forecast, in the federal budget, to be delivered by the $166 billion sovereign wealth fund, The Australian Financial Review revealed in April.

Return to surplus

The fund's profits will not count towards the Morrison government's acclaimed return to surplus, forecast to be $7.1 billion in 2019-20.

Since the fund's inception, under former Liberal federal treasurer and now Future Fund chairman Peter Costello, the earnings by the investment vehicle have not been included in the budget's underlying cash balance.

Mr Costello set up the fund when he was treasurer in 2006 to pay for the unfunded pension liabilities of public servants.

He is also chairman of Nine, owner of the Financial Review.

Separately, a report in March by the parliament's independent fiscal watchdog said the government's net debt could be higher by as much as $70 billion if the Future Fund's investments were accounted for differently in the Commonwealth budget.

Advertisement

Almost half the Future Fund's investments are made via collective investment vehicles, such as equity-like assets in private equity and infrastructure, and are currently deducted from the government's gross debt.

However, if the sovereign wealth fund held the same equity investments directly, under budget accounting rules they would not reduce the government's reported net debt to the current $373 billion, the Parliamentary Budget Office said.

The watchdog's report called into question the appropriateness of the longstanding net debt frameworks adopted under Coalition and Labor governments and suggested that a review was warranted and greater transparency required in the budget to report the holdings of government investment funds.

"Additional transparency around the treatment of these investment fund assets would aid public understanding given their size and growing impact," it said.
description: Finance Minister Mathias Cormann said the provision for the unfunded super liability was affected by budget accounting rules.
